contents: Between the years 1845 and 1852, Ireland endured seven years of mass starvation known today as “The Great Hunger.” Approximately one million people starved to death, and another two million fled in an effort to save themselves and their families. The immediate cause of the famine was a blight, or famine, that killed potato crops throughout Europe. Ireland suffered most from the potato blight because a third of its population was totally dependent on the potato crop for survival.
